concern:
Hey, so I'm going to CSUS and taking the ALEKs Math test very soon and I'm very worried I wont do well because this math goes very far back and there's lots of things I've forgotten. I've taken all the possible math courses at my high school- all the way up to Calculus AB and BC (but I didn't pass the AP test so I have to take calculus in college) and I'm currently in AP Stats. I'm just worried that if I bomb this test they're going to put me in a super low math class. 

In all the math classes I've taken I've gotten A's so... would they still put me in a low math class if I bomb the test even though my transcript shows that I've aced all the higher math classes I've taken? 

I would really appreciate any help/responses because this has been stressing me out a lot. Also, maybe this isn't the correct subreddit to post this question in, so I apologize if that's the case. But, I couldn't find a better place and this still applies to college and applications.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome! Please feel free to share anything that's on your mind or any concerns you might have. I'm here to listen and help in any way I can.

Hey, thanks for that. I'm just really stressed about this math placement test I have to take soon. I feel like I've forgotten a lot of the old stuff and I’m worried it might mess up my college math classes.

therapist: It sounds like you're feeling stressed because you're concerned that forgetting some material might affect your upcoming placement test and future classes. What has your experience with math been like in the past?

client: Well, I've always done pretty well in my math classes, like getting A's and everything. But I didn't pass the AP Calculus test, so that's making me doubt myself a bit now, especially with this placement test coming up.

It seems like you're feeling doubtful about your math abilities because of that one experience with the AP Calculus test, even though you've generally done well in math classes. Can you tell me more about what it was like when you were preparing for your previous math tests?

I usually felt pretty confident when preparing for math tests in high school, but I had a solid routine and support from teachers and classmates. This time around, it's more self-directed, and I'm worried I won't remember everything I need to.

It sounds like having a routine and support was really beneficial for you in the past. How do you think establishing some of that structure again might help with your confidence as you prepare for this placement test?
Yeah, having a routine definitely helped back then. I think recreating some structure might make me feel more on top of things, but I'm not sure where to start without the usual school support.

It seems like you're recognizing the importance of having a routine and support in boosting your confidence. On a scale from 0 to 10, how confident do you feel about creating a new structure for yourself as you prepare for this placement test?
client: Hmm, I’d say maybe a 4 or 5? I know what worked for me before, but it's just hard to figure out how to adapt that to this new situation without the same resources.

Therapist: It sounds like you're acknowledging both your past successes and the current challenges you're facing, which is really insightful. What might help you move from a 4 or 5 to feeling more confident, say around a 6 or 7, as you work to create this new structure?

client: I think maybe having a plan or some guidance on where to focus my study efforts would help. Maybe if I could find someone to study with or resources similar to the ones I had in high school, I'd feel better about it.

It's great that you're identifying what could help increase your confidence. It seems like having a study partner or similar resources might bridge that gap for you. What resources or people do you think you could reach out to, to provide that support or guidance as you prepare for your test?

client: I guess I could start by reaching out to some classmates from my high school who might be in a similar boat, or maybe there's an online study group I could join. I could also check if there are any tutoring services or workshops offered by the school.

Those sound like solid ideas to build a supportive study environment. Based on what you mentioned, possible steps might be reaching out to old classmates, looking for online study groups, and checking out school resources like tutoring or workshops. What do you think about starting with one of these actions, and how do you envision overcoming any barriers that might arise?

I think reaching out to old classmates could be a good start, since we already know each other and might be going through the same thing. As for barriers, maybe just coordinating schedules could be tricky, but I’m hoping once we start talking, it’ll work itself out.

It sounds like you've really thought this through, and it's wonderful to see you taking proactive steps to prepare for your test. Reaching out to old classmates is a fantastic idea, and it's great that you're considering how to navigate potential scheduling issues. You've got a clear path ahead: connecting with your peers and exploring additional resources like online groups or school workshops. As you work on these steps, remember that your past successes are a testament to your resilience and capability. Trust in your ability to recreate a supportive study routine. Your plan is well on its way, and I believe in your ability to overcome any challenges. If you ever feel stuck or need further support, reaching out to school advisors or counselors could also be beneficial. Keep up the great work, and remember, you're not alone in this journey.
Thanks, I appreciate that. I’ll definitely keep those options in mind and see how it goes.
